entry.title: 8 Critical Pain Points of MCP in an Enterprise
entry.content:
The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is being hailed as the "USB port" for AI agents. But for the enterprise, it is currently a security "Wild West."

While MCP makes it easy to connect LLMs to data and tools, deploying it without a centralized gateway creates a fragmented environment where security policies are nearly impossible to enforce.

If you are moving AI agents from demo to production, here are 8 critical pain points:

  1. The Attribution Gap
    AI agents usually execute tools via service accounts. When a massive data export happens, your log shows "mcp-service-account" instead of the human employee who triggered it. This makes SOX and GDPR compliance impossible.

  2. Over-Privileged Access
    Most MCP setups are all-or-nothing. A user needing to view orders might accidentally inherit the ability to delete them because there is no granular, tool-by-tool authorization.

  3. No Central Kill Switch
    In a decentralized setup, there is no single control point. If a server is compromised, security teams must manually hunt and disconnect dozens of individual agent configurations while the breach spreads.

  4. The "Prompt-to-Delete" Risk
    Prompt injection is a real threat. Without human-in-the-loop gates, a cleverly worded prompt can trick an agent into executing high-risk actions like cleaning up a production database.

  5. Discovery Without Governance
    Currently, agents either see everything or nothing. We lack a middle ground where a user can discover a capability exists but must request formal permission before the agent can execute it.

  6. Cross-Tenant Contamination
    Without strict boundary enforcement, sensitive R&D or executive compensation data can leak into agents used by other departments, violating internal confidentiality.

  7. Forensic Nightmares
    Audit logs are scattered across dozens of servers in inconsistent formats. Correlating who did what and when after a breach takes weeks of manual work instead of minutes.

  8. Shadow AI Integrations
    Developers are already running local MCP servers on their laptops to test with production data. These bypass firewalls and leave zero audit trail, creating massive compliance holes.

The Model Context Protocol is the future of agentic workflows, but the direct connection model does not scale in a regulated environment. Enterprises need a centralized governance layer to enforce authentication and authorization before these agents are given the keys to the kingdom.

How is your team handling the security of AI tool-calling?

entry.title: Architecting MCP for the Enterprise
entry.content:
Architecting MCP for the Enterprise

In my previous post, I explained why deploying Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers through direct agent-to-server connections creates security and governance risks in enterprise environments.

This follow-up focuses on the architectural correction.

While working through the design of a centralized governance layer for MCP-based integrations, one conclusion became clear: MCP is not the problem, treating MCP as a point-to-point integration is.

The Architectural Gap

Most MCP deployments today follow a familiar pattern:

  • Agents connect directly to MCP servers

  • Tools execute using service accounts

  • Authorization, audit, and control are fragmented

This works for experimentation but breaks down once traceability, least privilege, auditability, and incident response become mandatory. Enterprises already solved this problem for APIs. MCP requires the same architectural discipline.

The Required Architectural Shift

The shift is toward a centralized control plane.

All MCP interactions should pass through a governance layer positioned between AI agents and MCP servers. This layer does not replace MCP, it standardizes how MCP is accessed and controlled.

How This Architecture Addresses the Key Pain Points

A centralized governance layer enables:

  • Identity attribution
    Every MCP action executes in the context of a real user identity, not a shared service account.

  • Least-privilege authorization
    Access is granted at the capability level, separating read, write, and destructive operations.

  • Centralized control and revocation
    MCP servers and permissions can be disabled instantly from a single control point.

  • Guardrails for destructive actions
    High-risk operations are denied by default and explicitly authorized.

  • Governed capability discovery
    Capabilities are visible, while execution remains controlled.

  • Tenant and domain isolation
    Consistent boundaries prevent cross-team and cross-tenant data exposure.

  • Centralized audit and forensics
    All MCP activity becomes queryable, not forensic.

  • Visibility into shadow AI usage
    A single governed access path makes MCP usage observable and controllable.

Technology-Agnostic by Design

This architecture aligns with established enterprise patterns:

  • Federated identity and access management

  • Policy-based authorization

  • Gateway or service-mesh enforcement

  • Centralized audit and observability

Technologies may vary. The architecture should not.

entry.title: The Problem: The "Static Wall" of Traditional Design
entry.content:
What is Generative UI?
Generative UI (GenUI) is a paradigm shift where the user interface is created, modified, or rearranged by AI in real-time. Instead of a static set of screens, the interface is a "chameleon" that reshapes itself based on the user's intent and context.

The Mechanics: How the Interface "Assembles" Itself
We‚Äôre moving away from "hard-coded" layouts toward a system of Real-time Assembly. You aren't letting an AI guess how to code a website from scratch; instead, you are giving it a brain and a toolbox.

Intent Decoding: The system analyzes the user‚Äôs natural language or behavior to identify the specific goal (e.g., "I need to compare these three service plans").
Component Orchestration: The AI selects the best visual tools from a library of pre-defined, high-quality building blocks such as interactive tables, scheduling widgets, or data visualizations.
Contextual Mapping: The system fetches the relevant data and maps it into the selected components, ensuring the right information sits in the right place.
On-Demand Rendering: The interface is delivered instantly to the user‚Äôs screen, appearing only when the logic of the conversation or task requires it.

Generative UI is a powerful evolution, but it requires a strategic balance.

The Advantages
Hyper-Personalization: The interface meets the user where they are, adapting to their skill level, their current device, and the specific complexity of their task.
Intuitive Discovery: It eliminates "feature fatigue." Instead of users hunting through complex navigation, the specific tool they need finds them.
Adaptive Accessibility: The UI can reshape itself to meet individual needs, automatically adjusting layouts, contrast, or simplicity for different accessibility requirements.
Systemic Scalability: Design and development teams can focus on building robust, reusable systems rather than spending time on every possible edge-case screen.

The Challenges
Consistency & Habit: Users rely on "muscle memory." If the interface changes too drastically every time it's used, it can create a sense of disorientation.
Reliability & Logic: Just as AI can produce incorrect text, it can potentially assemble a UI that is visually impressive but logically flawed or functionally broken.
Performance Overhead: Generating and rendering custom components on the fly requires more processing power and lower latency than serving a static page.
Contextual Privacy: To be truly helpful, these systems require deep context about the user‚Äôs intent, necessitating a higher standard for data security and transparent handling.

The Verdict: Designing Systems, Not Pages
Generative UI represents the end of the "one-size-fits-all" software era. We are shifting from designing static pages to designing intelligent systems that can assemble themselves.

In this new world, the most successful interface won't be the one with the most features but it will be the one that is "smart" enough to get out of the user's way and provide exactly what they need, the moment they need it.

Are you ready to move beyond the static screen and start building "living" interfaces?

entry.title: New Machine Learning, NLP and AI features in SAP HANA Cloud 2025 Q3
entry.content:
With the SAP HANA Cloud 2025 Q3 release, several new embedded Machine Learning / AI functions have been released with the SAP HANA Cloud Predictive Analysis Library (PAL) and the Automated Predictive Library (APL).

  • An enhancement summary is available in the What‚Äôs new document for SAP HANA Cloud database 2025.28 (QRC 3/2025).

 

Time series analysis and forecasting function enhancements

Threshold support in timeseries outlier detection

In time series, an outlier is a data point that is different from the general behavior of remaining data points.  In the PAL time series outlier detection function, the outlier detection task is divided into two steps

  • In step 1 the residual values are derived from the original series,
  • In step 2, the outliers are detected from the residual values.

Multiple methods are available to evaluate a data point to be an outlier or not.

  • Including Z1 score, Z2 score, IIQR score, MAD score, IsolationForest, DBSCAN
  • If used in combination, outlier voting can be applied for a combined evaluation. 

Now, new and in addition, thresholds values for outlier scores are supported

  • New parameter OUTPUT_OUTLIER_THRESHOLD
  • Based on the given threshold value, if the time series value is beyond the (upper and lower) outlier threshold for the time series, the corresponding data point as an outlier.
  • Only valid when outlier_method = 'iqr', 'isolationforest', 'mad', 'z1', 'z2'.

 

 

Classification and regression function enhancements

Corset sampling support with SVM models

Coreset sampling is a machine learning technique to

  • select a small, representative subset (the "coreset") from larger datasets,
  • enabling faster, more efficient training and processing while maintaining similar model accuracy as using the full data.
  • It works by identifying the most "informative" samples, filtering out redundant or noisy data, and allowing complex algorithms to run on a manageable dataset sizes.

Support Vector Machine (SVM) model training is computationally expensive, and computational costs are specifically sensitive to the number of training points, which makes SVM models often impractical for large datasets. 

Therefore SVM in the Predictive Analysis Library has been enhanced and now

  • offers embedded coreset sampling capabilities
  • enabled with the new parameters USE_CORESET and CORESET_SCALE as the sampling ratio when constructing coreset.

This enhancement significantly reduces SVM training time with minimal impact on accuracy.

 

 

AutoML and pipeline function enhancements

Target encoding support in AutoML 

The PAL AutoML framework introduces a new pipeline operator for target encoding of categorial features

  • Categorical data is often required to be preprocessed and required to get converted from non-numerical features into formats suitable for the respective machine learning algorithm, i.e. numeric values
    • Examples features: text labels (e.g., ‚Äúred,‚Äù ‚Äúblue‚Äù) or discrete categories (e.g., ‚Äúhigh,‚Äù ‚Äúmedium,‚Äù ‚Äúlow‚Äù)
  • One-hot encoding converts each categorial feature value  into a binary column (0 or 1), which works well for features with a limited number of unique values. PAL already applies an optimized one-hot encoding method aggregating very low frequent values.
  • Target encoding replaces the categorial values with the mean of the target / label column for high-cardinality features, which avoids to create large and sparse one-hot encoded feature matrices
    • Example of a high cardinality feature: ‚Äúcity‚Äù column with hundreds-thousands of unique values, postal code, product IDs etc.

The PAL AutoML engine will analyze the input feature cardinality and then automatically decide if to apply target encoding or another encoding method. For medium to high cardinality categorial features, target encoding may improve the performance significantly.

By automating target encoding, the PAL AutoML engine aims to improve model performance and generalization, especially when dealing with complex, high-cardinality categorical features, without requiring manual intervention.

In addition, the AutoML and pipeline function now also support columns of type half precision vector.

 

Misc. Machine Learning and statistics function enhancements

High-dimensional feature data reduction using UMAP

UMAP (Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection) is a non-linear dimensionality reduction algorithm used to simplify complex, high-dimensional feature spaces, while preserving its essential structure. It is widely considered the modern gold standard for visualizing targeted dimension reduction of large-scale datasets, because it balances computational speed with the ability to maintain both local and global relationships.

  • It reduces thousands of variables (dimensions) into 2D or 3D scatter plots that humans can easily interpret.
  • Unlike comparable methods like t-SNE, UMAP is better at preserving global structure, meaning the relative positions between different clusters remain more meaningful.
  • It is significantly faster and more memory-efficient than t-SNE, capable of processing datasets with millions of points in a reasonable timeframe.
  • It can be used as a "transformer" preprocessing step in Machine Learning scenarios to reduce large feature spaces before applying clustering (e.g., k-means, HDBSCAN) or classification models, often improving their performance.

The following new functions are introduced

  • _SYS_AFL.PAL_UMAP‚Äã with the most important parameters N_NEIGHBORS, MIN_DIST, N_COMPONENTS, DISTANCE_LEVEL‚Äã
  • _SYS_AFL.PAL_TRUSTWORTHINESS‚Äã, used to measure the structure similarity between original high dimensional space and embedded low dimensional space based on K nearest neighbors.

 

Calculating pairwise distances

Many algorithms, for example clustering algorithms utilize distance matrixes as a preprocessing step, often inbuild to the functions. While often there is the wish to decouple though the distance matrix calculation from the follow-up task like the actual clustering. Moreover, if decoupled custom calculated matrixes can be fed into algorithms as input.

  • Most PAL clustering functions support to feed-in a pre-calculated similarity matrix

Now, a dedicated pairwise distance calculation function is provided

  • It supports distance metrics like Manhattan, Euclidien, Minkowski, Chebyshey as well as Levenshtein
  • The Levenshtein distance (or ‚Äúedit distance‚Äù) is a distance metric specifically targeting distance between text-columns.
    • It calculates the minimum number of single-character edits (insertions, deletions, or substitutions) needed to transform one word into another, acting as a measure of their similarity. A lower distance indicates a higher similarity.

Applicable use cases

  • It is useful in data cleaning, table column similarity analysis between columns of the same data type.
  • After calculating the column similarity across all data types, clustering like K-Means can be applied to group similar fields and propose mappings for fields within the same cluster

 

Real Vector data type support

The following PAL functions have been enhanced to support columns of type real vector

  • Spectral Clustering
  • Cluster Assignment
  • Decision tree
  • Sampling

In addition the AutoML and pipeline function now also support columns of type half precision vector.

 

Creating Vector Embeddings enhancements

The SAP HANA Database Vector Engine function VECTOR_EMBEDDING() has added support for remote, SAP AI Core exposed embedding models. Detailed instruction are given in the documentation at Creating Text Embeddings with SAP AI Core | SAP Help Portal

 

Python ML client (hana-ml) enhancements

The full list of new methods and enhancements with hana_ml 2.26  is summarized in the changelog for hana-ml 2.26 as part of the documentation. The key enhancements in this release include

New Functions

  • Added text tokenization API.
  • Added explainability support with IsolationForest Outlier Detection
  • Added constrained clustering API.
  • Added intermittent time series data test in time series report.

Enhancements

  • Support time series SHAP visualizations for AutoML Timeseries model explanations

You can find an examples notebook illustrating the highlighted feature enhancements here 25QRC03_2.26.ipynb.

entry.title: The SAP Barbell Strategy: Applying Taleb‚Äôs Risk Logic to S/4HANA Projects
entry.content:
In the world of SAP S/4HANA transformations, project managers often try to "balance" risk. They aim for a middle-of-the-road approach: a bit of innovation here, a bit of customization there, and a moderate amount of testing but according to Nassim Taleb, author of The Black Swan and Antifragile, this "middle" is exactly where complex entities (like SAP projects) can die.

Taleb‚Äôs Barbell Strategy suggests that instead of being "medium-risky," you should be hyper-conservative on one side and hyper-aggressive on the other. By avoiding the middle, you protect yourself from total failure while keeping the door open for massive gains.

Here is a proposal to apply the Barbell Strategy to your SAP roadmap.

1. The Left Side: Extreme Safety (90% of Resources)

This side of the barbell is about survival. These are the areas where failure is an "existential risk"‚Äîmeaning if they break, the company stops functioning. Here, we do not innovate; we focus on absolute robustness.

  • Data Migration: Bad financial or inventory data is a "Black Swan" event that can kill a Go-live. The Barbell approach requires extreme redundancy: multiple mock migrations, rigorous data cleansing, and third-party audits.
  • Clean Core (The Standard): Staying with the SAP Standard is your insurance policy. Every modification to the core system increases "fragility." By keeping the core clean, you ensure that future upgrades are seamless and the system remains stable.
  • Business Continuity: Can you issue an invoice on Day 1? Can you ship a pallet? This is the "Zero Day" requirement. Every resource here should be focused on ensuring the lights stay on when the legacy system is switched off.
  • Organizational Change Management (OCM): The biggest risk isn't technical‚Äîit's human. If your power users refuse to use the system, the project fails. Extreme safety means over-investing in training and user adoption early in the cycle.

2. The Right Side: Optionality and "Upside" (10% of Resources)

This is where you place small, speculative bets. These risks have a limited downside (if they fail, the cost is small) but an unlimited upside (if they work, they transform the business).

  • BTP Innovations: Use the SAP Business Technology Platform to run small AI or Machine Learning pilots. Automating a niche invoice-matching process might cost very little to try, but if it works, it saves thousands of man-hours.
  • Service Virtualization & Automated Simulation: Instead of waiting for third-party providers (banks, logistics partners, or external warehouses) to be "ready" for a test, you use tools like Int4 Suite or simulate virtualize their systems. The Unlimited Upside: You decouple your project timeline from external vendors. This can accelerate a global rollout by months. If you can test your SAP system‚Äôs integration with a "virtual" shipping partner before they even build their API, you find bugs early that would otherwise crash your Go-live.
  • Predictive Analytics: Experiment with advanced reporting models. Giving the C-suite a "future-view" that competitors lack provides a massive competitive advantage.
  • Low-Code/No-Code: Empower selected Power Users to build their own micro-tools using SAP Build. This encourages "bottom-up" innovation without touching the Clean Core.

3. The "Death Zone": The Fragile Middle (Avoid This)

The most dangerous part of an SAP project is the middle‚Äîthe "moderate" risks that seem safe but are actually fragile. These offer no protection against catastrophe and no potential for high-reward innovation.

  • The "Medium Seniority" Pricing War - the Trap: Spending weeks in procurement battles trying to find consultants who are "experienced but affordable." Why it looks productive: You feel like you are being a "smart shopper" by avoiding the $2,000/day architect and rejecting the $300/day junior. Maybe you need to use the Barbell strategy once more? 
  • The "Perfect" Non-Core Process - the Trap: Spending months in workshops refining "nice-to-have" processes like Internal Office Supplies Requisition or Travel Expense Approval Workflows. Why it looks productive: You are "closing gaps" and making the system "user-friendly" for everyone in the company.

Do you know any other activities which fall into this category? 

Conclusion: Becoming Antifragile

To make your SAP implementation antifragile, stop trying to find a "balance."

  1. Protect the Base: Be a paranoid conservative regarding finance, master data, and the Clean Core (the left side).
  2. Hunt for Opportunity: Allocate a small, dedicated budget for risky, low-cost technological experiments that can give you a market edge (the right side).
  3. Cut the Middle: Refuse to accept mediocre talent, complex code modifications, and "vague" project scopes.

In the Barbell method, you aren't balancing risk; you are being extremely safe and extremely aggressive at the same time.

Additional Materials: Strengthening the Right Side of the Barbell

To move from the "Fragile Middle" to an Antifragile project state, you need the right tooling. While standard SAP tools handle the core, specialized solutions are required to manage the complexity of modern integrations and external dependencies.

Technical Spotlight: Int4 Suite

The Int4 Suite is a specialized SAP add-on designed to help enterprise companies master SAP Integration through Service Virtualization and automated API Testing.

In the context of the Barbell Strategy, Int4 Suite acts as a force multiplier for your "Right Side" (Optionality). It allows large organizations to ensure their interfaces, whether with banks, logistics providers, or external cloud platforms, work perfectly long before the actual SAP project Go-live. By virtualizing these third-party systems, you eliminate the "waiting game" for external vendors, allowing your team to test early, test often, and discover integration "Black Swans" when they are still cheap to fix.

entry.title: The Secret Shopper for SAP Agents: Why Enterprise AI Needs a Reality Check with Int4 Suite
entry.content:
The enterprise software world is currently ‚Äúa bit‚Äù obsessed with "Agentic AI". We‚Äôre moving away from rigid, click-here-then-there workflows toward SAP Joule agents, autonomous entities that can reason, use tools, and execute complex business processes like the ones show in the figure below: 

Figure 1 - SAP Joule Agents 

But as we hand the keys of our SAP S/4HANA systems over to these digital coworkers, we face a fundamental crisis: The Death of Determinism. For decades, software testing followed a simple rule: Input X + Logic F = Output Y. It was predictable. With AI agents, that‚Äôs gone. An agent might solve the same problem three different ways on three different days. This creates a "Verification Gap" where traditional testing fails. If your AI agent "hallucinates" a successful transaction that never actually hits the database, your supply chain doesn't just slow down, it breaks. Here is why your enterprise needs a new way to test, and how Int4 Suite is stepping in as an Enterprise AI validator or in some business scenarios as a "Secret Shopper" for the AI era.

The Hallucination Trap: Why "Polite" AI Isn't Enough for Enterprise AI 

Most AI testing tools today are Guardrail Platforms. They are like bouncers at a club: they make sure the AI doesn't say anything offensive, leak a credit card number, or succumb to a prompt injection attack.

While essential for security, these tools have a massive blind spot: Functional Integrity. If SAP Joule Agents tells you, "I‚Äôve processed that sales order for you!" with a polite digital smile, but it actually failed to map the tax jurisdiction code correctly in SAP S/4HANA, the "security" tools won't catch it. They validate the Tool Call (what the agent intended to do), but they don't validate the Tool Execution (what actually happened in the database).

The "Secret Shopper" Scenario: Order-to-Cash

Imagine you want to check the quality of service at a high-end retail store. You don't just ask the manager if the staff is good; you send in a Secret Shopper, a person with a specific script who tests the system's limits and reports back on exactly what happened.

In the world of SAP S/4HANA, Int4 Suite acts as that Secret Shopper for the Order-to-Cash (O2C) process. Here‚Äôs how the "Mission" looks:

  1. The Trigger: A customer sends an email with an attached PDF order.

  2. The Agent's Job: SAP Joule (the AI agent) must read the email, parse the PDF, and autonomously create a Sales Order, an Outbound Delivery, and an Invoice in SAP S/4HANA.

Figure 2 - Order to Cash process started by a PDF inside an e-mail, processed by the AI Agent completely 

  1. The Int4 Suite "Mission":

  • Fetch & Fabricate: Int4 Suite fetches a real historical email and PDF from your system using its Robotic Crawler. It then dynamically changes the values (unique qualifier like the Order reference, etc.) so the test is unique and won't clash with existing data.

  • The Sting: Int4 Suite resends this unique "mystery" order to the AI agent.

  • The Deep Audit: This is where Int4 Suite shines. While other tools just watch the "chat," Int4 Suite goes into the SAP S/4HANA backend. It validates the resulting documents up to the field level.

Figure 3 - Replication of the original process by this time completely run by Int4 Suite and validated in the SAP S/4HANA DB. 

Did the agent correctly calculate the net value? Is the shipping point correct? Did the invoice trigger the right accounting document? Int4 Suite compares the agent's work against historical "gold standard" documents to ensure 100% accuracy.

Figure 4 - SAP S/4HANA DB validation of a sales order posting 

The FWE Model: A New Standard for AI Validation

To truly trust an AI agent, you need a Functional Workflow Execution (FWE) model. This is the architectural loop that Int4 Suite has perfected:

  • Technical Flow Implementation: Setting up the "harness" where the agent lives.

  • Test Case Definition: Defining what "success" actually looks like - Order posted with a certain number of lines, Delivery posted with certain quantities, etc..

Figure 5 - Test Workflow definition inside Int4 Suite 

  • Dynamic Data Fabrication: Using the Robotic Crawler to mine historical messages and "seed" the test environment with valid, complex data.

  • Agent Execution: Letting the AI run wild in a deterministic "sandbox."

  • Backend Validation: Programmatically inspecting SAP S/4HANA database entries, IDocs, and API responses to verify the "side effects" of the AI‚Äôs actions.

Why Int4 Suite‚Äôs approach is Unique? 

While the market is flooded with "AI Security" startups, they lack the "plumbing" to talk to SAP. Int4 Suite was born in the world of SAP integration (PI/PO, CPI). It speaks the language of IDocs, OData, APIs in general.

We are witnessing a shift from deterministic chains to probabilistic agents. You can't test a probabilistic agent with a spreadsheet and a prayer.

If you are deploying SAP Joule, you need a validator that doesn't just listen to what the agent says, but verifies what the agent did. By leveraging service virtualization and deep backend inspection, Int4 Suite ensures that your "Secret Shopper" tests don't just find hallucinations, they build a foundation of enterprise-grade trust.

Ready to send a Secret Shopper into your S/4HANA system? It‚Äôs time to move beyond the chat bubble and into the database.

entry.title: Joule Studio: How to Create Document Grounding
entry.content:
Several people have reached out to me this week to describe the new way you set up document grounding with Joule Studio. So here goes.

What is Document Grounding

Many of you may know about Document Grounding, but for those who don't here's a very brief explanation.

  1. The basic way we use AI is to send a prompt to an LLM (a set of "indexed" information).
  2. If we want the LLM to take into account additional information it may not have, we can provide "context" (though the amount of "context" you are allowed to send may be constrained).

One of those pieces of context may come from a set of documents (e.g., housed in SharePoint or in the SAP BTP Object Store service). In order to use those documents as context we must perform Document Grounding, which takes the documents, "chunks" them into small pieces, and then "embeds" them so they can be used as context in our AI requests.

In Joule Studio, when we create agents, we essentially specify an LLM to handle specific types of prompts, and then provide context and instructions for what we want the agent to do.

The "Old" Way in Joule Studio

The old way we performed Document Grounding in Joule Studio was to go into AI Core and create a resource group, connect that resource group to a content store (e.g., the place we store the documents), and have AI Core chunk and embed the documents so we could use the content within an agent or for use when sending a prompt to AI Core. Joule Studio would be configured to connect with a specific AI Core, and the developer of an agent would type in the name of a resource group in AI Core to use with their agent.

Here we can see in the SAP AI Launchpad that we are connected to the "dbw" resource, and we have created a "pipeline" with documents.

If we click inside, we can see that this pipeline has 4 documents, each chunked and embedded. 

But doing this required going into the SAP AI Launchpad, creating Generic Secrets by encoding credentials in Base64, and several more steps in tools we may not be familiar with.

Joule Studio still makes use of the same mechanism in AI Core, but now takes care of creating all the artifacts behind the scene (and enables some new capabilities).  

 

1. Prerequisites

You need an instance of SAP AI Core and an S3-compatible document store such as the Object Store service in BTP. I won't go into setting these up, but you can find out more information here:

  • AI Core
  • Object Store

If you need more information, leave a comment.

Note you can define many instances of AI Core and Object Store to be used with Joule Studio.

 

2. Destinations

You need to set up destinations to AI Core and Object Store on both your SAP Build tenant and your Joule tenant. 

AI Core Destination

Get the service key of your AI Core instance, and create a destination as shown below.

Append /oauth/token to the url value of the service key and use this for the destination's Token Service URL.

Add the additional property sap-joule-studio-document-grounding-ai-core and set it to true. This makes the destination visible within the SAP Build Control Tower.

 

Object Store Destination

Similarly, get the service key for the object store service instance and set the following destination fields with the corresponding service field value:

Destination FieldService Key Field
URLaccess_key_id
Client IDhost (add https://)
Client Secretsecret_access_key
Token Service URLhost (add https://)

Add the following additional properties:

Additional PropertyValue
regionregion value from service key
bucketbucket value from service key
usernameusername value from service key
typeS3
sap-joule-studio-document-grounding-object-store
true

The additional property sap-joule-studio-document-grounding-object-store makes the destination visible within the SAP Build Control Tower.

 

3. Set Up in Control Tower

In the Control Tower, the SAP Build admin will decide:

  • From which object stores to create Document Grounding.
  • In which AI Core instances to create these Document Grounding pipelines.

The Control Tower now has a Joule section, including a Document Grounding tile so the admin can create Document Grounding and make it available to Joule Studio developers.

Click the Document Grounding tile. You can now create sets of Document Grounding.

Note that while in the SAP AI Launchpad you could create different pipelines with different sets of documents in the same resource group, here each object store will create a separate resource group.

Click Add.

Give the resource group a name.

Select the AI Core instance in which to create the resource group.

And finally select the object store whose documents you want to ground.

Click Add.

The status of the resource group will be Pending. 

After about a minute (depending on the size of the documents), the status will change to Completed.

(Early on, I occasionally got Error messages, or Pending simply remained for a long time, and sometimes they would alternate between those messages. In such cases, make sure the destinations are configured properly and make sure the documents in the Object Store are not corrupted.)

If you now look in SAP AI Launchpad, and go to SAP AI Core Administration > Resource Groups, you will see a new resource group whose name is the name you specified (without spaces) with a Unix timestamp appended.

Though the resource group should immediately appear on the Resource Groups page, it may take a few extra minutes for the resource group to appear on the Workspaces page. 

Once it does, you can select it and see the pipeline and Document Grounding inside the resource group. 

 

4. Add Document Grounding to Your Agent 

Now that the admin has set up a resource group and triggered the document grounding for a set of documents, developers of Joule Studio agents can use them in their agents.

Inside an agent, the developer can specify tools, including documents. Select Add Tools > Documents.

This opens a dialogue to specify which resource group created by the admin to use. Specify a name for the documents (as seen in the agent) and a description to help the agent know when to use them.

Then select from among the resource groups created by the admin.

Advantages

The advantages of this method are:

  • Admins and developers no longer have to work in AI Launchpad, including creating Generic Secrets and dealing with Base64 encoding of credentials.
  • Admins decide what document grounding gets used in Joule Studio agents.
    • From the look of the UI, admins will eventually be able to assign a resource group to a specific environment, giving admins even more control
  • Developers have a predefined set of  resource groups to choose from, using a dropdown list.
  • More than one AI Core instance and more than one Object Store instance can be used to define document grounding for a Joule Studio.

Note that this method creates a single document grounding pipeline in each resource group it creates; using AI Launchpad, you can create multiple pipelines in a single resource group.

There may be more advantages and limitations. Please add a comment with your opinion about this feature, or anything I missed.

entry.title: My highlights of the SAP Cloud ERP 2602 release
entry.content:
Welcome to 2026 and welcome to my SAP Cloud ERP 2602 product release highlights! This blog post guides you through the key improvements of the 2602 release of SAP Cloud ERP, focusing on how they support customers in running and evolving their core business processes. And it was again not easy to decide what to declare as highlights amongst the large number of innovations delivered. It's our 34th major release over the years, and I have collected an interesting range across functional, foundational and user experience capabilities. And of course, the AI journey continues to boost both well-known and new ERP processes to a new levels. We're all in on AI.

I wish the team would have granted me more space to talk you through all innovation shipped with the 2602 release , take this blog post as an appetizer for our team‚Äôs deep dive blogs per line of business. Prefer video over text? Take a look at my product update video, where my digital twin guides you through the key highlights. 

 

A new operating model for integrated business processes 

With the first release of 2026, we walk the talk of our SAP Business Suite and introduce a range of SAP-managed Integrated Business Processes, removing the complexity of integrating and monitoring multiple cloud solutions from our customer's and partner's activity list. We have carefully listened to your wishes and SAP delivers co-provisioning, functional and technical integration, including lifecycle management, allowing these activities to move in the background while customers focus on their core business. By shifting responsibility for aligned system provisioning, functional and technical integration, and lifecycle management from customers to SAP, we reduce complexity behind the scenes and enables a more seamless suite experience.

* Click here to access the links mentioned in the slide above

As an initial step, release 2602 delivers SAP-managed integration for two critical end-to-end processes as part of an Early Adopter Care (EAC) program. In Workforce Management, SAP provides SAP-managed provisioning and integration between SAP Cloud ERP and SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, supporting a streamlined Recruit-to-Retire process with consistent employee and financial data from day one. For Operational Procurement, integrated processes across SAP Cloud ERP, SAP Ariba Buying, and SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management simplify Procure-to-Pay activities and support a more unified procurement landscape.

These capabilities are enabled by blueprint-based provisioning, which changes how solution instances are deployed, integrated, and managed across the run phase. Instead of manual setup, customers can activate selective solutions or in the future complete suites that are provisioned and come already fully integrated together. Guided by a new suite experience in SAP for Me and based on SAP landscape modeling best practices, SAP applies a desired-state-based reconciliation to ensure transparency, consistency, and long-term stability across the application landscape.

 

AI innovations

SAP Joule for Consultants: Practical enhancements for your everyday project work

With this first release of year 2026, SAP Joule for Consultants continues to mature as a day-to-day companion for project focused workers, offering efficient access to trusted content, better transparency, and smoother workflows ‚Äì on demand. A new SAP Joule for Consultants console brings ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs New‚Äô release notes, an integrated prompt library, and, where relevant, administrative insights such as usage metrics and system settings into one central entry point, helping teams stay aligned with current innovations.

 

 

Joule now also surfaces SAP Notes and SAP Knowledge Base Articles (KBAs) directly within conversations, based on existing customer entitlements. This allows consultants to reference validated SAP guidance without leaving their context, while administrators retain control through standard s-user assignments. Usability improvements further support efficient work: Quick links simplify navigation across Joule features, the conversation character limit has been increased to 10,000 characters to accommodate larger inputs such as code or detailed scenarios, and public SAP content sources have been refreshed and expanded.

Enhanced citation visibility improves transparency by clearly indicating the origin of information, including public web sources when applicable.

 

Finally, the initial ingestion of SAP Signavio Process Navigator reference content lays the groundwork for more architecture-aware guidance in future releases.

 

Finance

Accounting Accruals Agent (beta)

In the dynamic landscape of financial management, the introduction of the beta version of Accounting Accruals Agent marks a thoughtful stride towards empowering finance professionals with innovative tools tailored for efficiency. This intelligent agent draws from AI-driven capabilities to meticulously craft accrual proposals, transforming the traditionally labor-intensive process into a streamlined operation. By analyzing accounting policy documents, sifting through historical data, and executing precise calculations, this agent reduces the substantial time accountants typically spend during period-end accruals. The newfound simplicity in the ‚ÄòManage Accrual Proposals‚Äô app not only enhances the speed of reviewing and posting proposals but also offers detailed, AI-backed explanations for each calculated entry. This ensures that general ledger accountants gain not just time but also trust in AI‚Äôs role in augmenting their decision-making processes, thereby enabling a smoother and more efficient period-end close. This feature is going to be made generally available in SAP Cloud ERP 2602.

 

SAP User Experience

AI-assisted task automation (beta)

In everyday work, many tasks in SAP Cloud ERP follow the same patterns: Reviewing data, triggering follow-up steps, or keeping processes moving. With AI-assisted task automation, SAP introduces smart helpers that support users exactly in these moments. Built with generative AI and embedded directly in My Home, these helpers can take over routine steps within SAP applications while keeping users in control whenever decisions or data changes are required. Instead of replacing human judgement, the focus is on reducing manual effort and helping users progress through their tasks more smoothly. Over time, this creates a more natural way of working with automation, one that adapts to real user needs and daily workflows. Customers interested in shaping this capability early can join the beta program to explore the feature and provide feedback that will influence future AI-driven experiences in SAP Cloud ERP.

Check out this link to sign up for the beta testing and shape the future of AI innovations: https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#campaign/4086 

 

Retail

Assortment module management 

Many non-retail industries integrate retail capabilities into their ERP systems to enhance customer services and collaboration, even in B2B. Most organizations today are expected to react faster to changing customer expectations while keeping operations efficient and scalable. This requires tools that simplify everyday work for planners and merchandisers, reduce operational friction, and make it easier to translate data and insights into action. In this context, intelligent assistance within core retail processes becomes increasingly important, especially where decisions around assortments directly influence customer experience and business outcomes.

In the area of Retail, Joule‚Äôs integration into assortment module management supports planners by making common tasks more accessible and less time-consuming. Instead of navigating multiple screens, users can rely on natural language interactions to create, update, or terminate assortments directly within the application. This reduces dependency on deep technical knowledge and helps teams complete routine tasks with greater confidence and efficiency. As a result, merchandising and category managers can spend less time on operational steps and more time focusing on assortment strategy and customer-centric planning.

For more information, please consult SAP Help Portal.

 

Asset Management

Maintenance notification creation and screening with Joule

In Asset Management, keeping maintenance processes running smoothly depends on timely and accurate notifications, often created under time pressure and by users outside of specialized maintenance roles. With Joule integrated into the maintenance notification process in SAP Cloud ERP, creating and screening notifications becomes more straightforward and accessible. Users can describe an issue in natural language and capture key details such as the technical object, priority, and description without navigating complex transaction flows. Moreover, users can access notifications in the ‚ÄòManage Maintenance Notification‚Äô SAP Fiori app (F5777), enabling quick acceptance and conversion into maintenance orders within a single conversational context. As a result, operators spend less time on documentation, while maintenance teams and managers benefit from clearer, more consistent information to plan and execute maintenance activities effectively.

 

SAP Activate innovations

SAP Activate introduces several innovations for the 2602 release, starting with a dedicated activation and implementation guidance for customers adopting SAP-managed integrations in the Early Adopter Care program, mentioned earlier.

Customers implementing SAP Cloud ERP will continue to benefit from easier access to implementation information with Joule, which is embedded in the ‚ÄôRoadmap Viewer‚Äô application on SAP for Me. Additionally, implementation teams can access up-to-date implementation guidance in nine languages: Chinese, English, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Portuguese, and Spanish. Change your language preferences in SAP for Me to view content in another language.

Customers conducting the upgrade to the 2602 release can leverage the lean upgrade roadmap in the ‚ÄòRoadmap Viewer‚Äô app or in SAP Cloud ALM to guide their team through the upgrade and post-upgrade activities. 

 

SAP Cloud ALM updates

In transformation projects, teams often invest a lot of time turning workshop outcomes, documents, and process discussions into structured requirements and test assets. With the latest updates in SAP Cloud ALM, this work becomes more streamlined across the project lifecycle. AI-assisted  requirements generation helps teams create initial requirements automatically based on Fit-to-Standard workshop transcripts, solution processes, and other project documentation, giving project members a solid starting point that can be reviewed and refined instead of built from scratch.

As project scopes evolve, requirements can now be moved easily between projects, supporting reuse and reducing duplication.

 

 Further enhancements focus on governance and test preparation.

New APIs for manual test cases, process hierarchies, and features make it easier to integrate SAP Cloud ALM into existing tool landscapes and automate project reporting or oversight. All SAP Cloud ALM APIs can be found on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

During test preparation, teams can now define where screenshots are required as test evidence, improving transparency and auditability during execution.

 

Updates to release assessment and scope dependency

Smarter upgrades in SAP Cloud ERP require a clear understanding of customer¬¥s individually relevant applications and scope items. The release assessment and scope dependency (RASD) tool continues to evolve, incorporating customer feedback to make impact analysis more transparent and easier to work with. Recent updates simplify how assessment results are shared, allowing users to download content across all tiles, or selected ones, into a single ZIP file with structured Excel outputs that can be reviewed, filtered, and discussed across distributed project teams.

Beyond usability improvements, RASD now provides more precise guidance for upgrade decisions. The introduction of a successor view helps identify recommended follow-on apps, supporting smoother transition planning.

In addition, enhanced views in the personalized 'What‚Äôs New Viewer' clearly differentiate between activated, used, and impacted scope items, helping teams focus on what truly matters in their system.

Together, these enhancements support more informed discussions, reduce uncertainty during release preparation, and help teams approach upgrades with greater clarity and confidence.

 

Other innovations across various LoBs

Supply Chain Management ‚Äì Warehouse management

Interface to warehouse automation systems for efficiently processing warehouse orders

In the evolving landscape of warehouse management, the integration of warehouse automation systems is set to significantly enhance operational efficiency. By seamlessly distributing warehouse orders to automated subsystems, businesses can ensure smooth and coordinated task execution. This interface not only sends out orders but also receives confirmations of warehouse tasks, creating a continuous feedback loop that ensures transparency and efficiency. Such integration significantly cuts down manual intervention, allowing for a more streamlined process that minimizes errors and enhances productivity. The main advantage lies in the ability to process warehouse orders more efficiently, capitalizing on automation to handle tasks that were once labor-intensive. This means warehouse operations can maintain a high level of accuracy while handling greater volumes, ultimately enhancing the overall supply chain performance and reliability.

 

 

Manufacturing

Production order combination enablement

In the Manufacturing line of business, we are happy to introduce production order combination enablement, which offers a practical solution to streamline operations and enhance efficiency. By merging identical operations from different production orders into a single consolidated order, manufacturers can optimize their processes right from the ‚ÄòManage Production Orders‚Äô app. This functionality allows for the creation, maintenance, and confirmation of combined orders, which in turn supports effective cost distribution and settlement through new event-based costing. By reducing setup times and overhead charges, this approach not only increases production throughput but also achieves considerable cost savings. This feature empowers manufacturers to focus their efforts on boosting output while maintaining a keen eye on cost efficiency, creating a more agile and responsive production environment.

 

Professional Services

Intercompany cost allocations reconciliation review booklet

In the Professional Services domain, the enhancement of the ‚ÄòIntercompany Review Booklet‚Äô app offers a significant boost in transparency and traceability for intercompany cost allocations. By displaying the complete end-to-end document flow, this app helps reconcile management accounting postings with billing and accounts receivable documents. This comprehensive view is invaluable during closing procedures, as it allows businesses to ensure their data's completeness by clearly identifying services and expenses that have been billed, are partially billed, or remain unbilled. Furthermore, the app provides audit-relevant information on billed intercompany services, offering businesses the assurance and documentation needed for clear internal and external audits. This capability aids organizations in maintaining robust financial processes while enhancing their ability to track and manage intercompany transactions efficiently. Starting with release 2602, the report will include an enhanced breakdown of billed entries, tracing them all the way to the receiver FI journal entry/affiliated expenses.  

 

Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management

Enhanced integration of project plan information with SAP Cloud ERP

In the domain of Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management, enhancing the integration of project plan information with SAP Cloud ERP was one of the items discussed and designed in our customer product councils. This innovation facilitates seamless synchronization of project plan data between SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Project and Resource Management, enabling a more cohesive project management experience. Users can manually trigger updates to project dates in SAP Cloud ERP, ensuring that information remains current and accurate. Furthermore, the automated bi-directional synchronization of project plan data significantly reduces the manual effort involved in data maintenance, allowing teams to focus on strategic initiatives. With greater scope control and improved integration, organizations can enjoy comprehensive visibility of critical information across different solutions, thus enhancing data quality and operational efficiency. This development empowers project managers with the tools needed to effectively monitor and control project progress, fostering better decision-making and resource allocation throughout the project lifecycle.

 

Summary

I hope this overview of the SAP Cloud ERP 2602 release highlights has provided helpful insights into the latest updates and enhancements as well as excitement for the upgrade. As SAP Cloud ERP continues to evolve, these innovations aim to support more efficient processes, clearer guidance, and a smoother experience across implementations and upgrades.

Let me know which innovation stands out most to you and what your personal highlights from this release are: Feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

In the coming weeks, we‚Äôll take a closer look at additional business- and industry-specific innovations in follow-up blogs. Be sure to visit our community page to connect with SAP experts, ask questions, and exchange feedback. To stay up to date with future content, follow the PSCC_Enablement tag and keep an eye out for upcoming posts.

Feel free to follow me at BeSchulze in the community and on LinkedIn to not miss any updates. 

Let‚Äôs keep advancing together‚Äîtowards a smarter, more connected cloud ERP future.

Yours,

entry.title: AI innovations highlights in SAP Cloud ERP 2602
entry.content:
The release of SAP Cloud ERP 2602 continues SAP‚Äôs focus on embedding intelligence directly into business processes, quietly, purposefully, and where it matters most. In this blog, you‚Äôll find a guided look at the key AI innovations introduced with the 2602 release, as highlighted in the product blog post by Bert Schulze. Rather than showcasing AI as a standalone capability, the focus is on how these innovations support customers in running, adapting, and evolving their core business processes across finance, sales, manufacturing, procurement, and beyond.

With the 2602 release, SAP Cloud ERP builds on its existing foundation by supporting everyday work with intelligence that is more contextual, connected, and task focused. At the heart of this evolution is an agentic AI framework, where specialized, task-specific agents take on clearly defined responsibilities based on real business context, data, and rules. These agents work together behind the scenes, while Joule serves as the orchestration layer that brings insights, recommendations, and next steps together in a natural, conversational way. Whether supporting a finance expert with complex classifications or helping teams respond faster to operational issues, intelligence is applied exactly where decisions are made. Take a moment to explore the accompanying video for a closer look at how these AI-driven capabilities quietly support everyday work and point toward a more adaptive way of running enterprise processes.

Take a look at the short video below to see how these AI-driven capabilities quietly support everyday work and are shaping a more adaptive way of running enterprise processes.

 

Agentic AI use case highlights

Finance

International Trade Classification Agent (beta)

When a single misclassified product can delay a shipment or trigger compliance questions, international trade classification quickly becomes a task where precision matters as much as speed. Inthe 2602 release, the International Trade Classification Agent supports product classification specialists in this sensitive part of the process by reasoning over product characteristics and applicable trade regulations. It proposes customs tariff numbers and commodity codes and explains how each recommendation was derived, making review and approval straightforward. This shifts the expert‚Äôs role from manual lookup to informed validation, while keeping full transparency and auditability. In practice, teams can expect significantly less effort spent on repetitive classification tasks, up to a 50% reduction, while lowering the risk of non-compliance.

 

Accounting Accruals Agent

Period-end accruals are a familiar pressure point in finance: important, repetitive, and often constrained by tight timelines. The beta version of the Accounting Accruals Agent tackles this challenge by supporting teams with proposing accruals based on accounting policy documents, historical data, and calculated values, helping shift the work from manual preparation to focused review.
